title: The association between phonological and morphological development in children at risk of language and literacy difficulties: A longitudinal follow up
abstractText:
It is well known that phonological skills are important predictors of literacy, but less is known about the influence of non-phonological language skills (eg, understanding and using words and sentences). In order to examine this, 198 children will be assessed, 82 of whom have increased risk of language and literacy difficulties.

These children have already been recruited and tested twice, once at school entry (Time 1) and again six months later (Time 2). They will now be retested at 7-9 years old. All children will be tested on reading comprehension as well at word reading and spelling skills. Time 1 phonological and non-phonological language measures will be used to predict progress. A sub-sample of 80 children will be selected on the basis of performance at Time 1 and will be given additional dynamic measures of phonological and morphological awareness. Longitudinal analysis will help clarify the relationships between phonology, morphology and literacy.

The research will help clarify the role of different language skills in the development of early literacy. Due to the broad range of abilities represented in our sample, the findings should be generalisable to both typically developing children and children with language impairments.
